description:
Really Bad Art is what you're making in this party game, but not because you're a terrible drawer, no — only because you have exactly six seconds to see what you're supposed to draw, then draw it!

Each round, each player secretly takes a card with two phrases like "lack of confidence", "quality of life", "constructive criticism", or "yikes!", then draws a representation of one of those phrases based on whichever color was chosen. Those cards are then shuffled with a dummy card and laid out next to the game board, after which everyone secretly votes on which piece of art corresponds to which card. Guess correctly, and you score two points; have others guess your phrase correctly, and you score one point.

Rounds continue until someone has scored thirty or more points and won the game!

1941: What If? An Alternative History Wargame of a Second Winter War is a low-to-intermediate complexity two-player alternative history wargame that’s also easily adaptable to solitaire play. It allows you to investigate the parameters inherent in the situation in Central Eastern Europe, at the end of 1940, had the Bulgarians decided to ally with the Soviets instead of the Germans, which historically they considered doing. Long story short (see the support article elsewhere in this issue), the result would’ve been the Second War’s eastern front erupting half a year prior to its historic start date under both natural and manmade conditions vastly different than pertained at that later date.

Each hexagon on the map represents 45 miles (73 km) from side to opposite side. Each turn represents a half a month of ‘real time.’ Each unit of maneuver represents an army or corps or ad hoc equivalent of those sizes of units.

The Soviet (a.k.a. “Soviet/Allied” or “Allied”) player commands all the Soviet units in the game along with those of Bulgaria, Greece and Britain. The German (a.k.a. “German/Axis” or “Axis”) player commands all the German units in the game, along with those of Turkey, Slovakia, Hungary, Romania and Italy. Yugoslavia starts the game neutral and out of play. Its government is leaning pro-Allied, however, and it will likely join the war on that side during the course of the game. When/if that occurs, the two Yugoslav-Croatian (4th and 7th) armies will either disintegrate, their soldiers dispersing to their homes, or join the Axis while the rest of the Yugoslav armed forces fight in the Allied side.

The orders of battle contain pretty all the units present in these armies at this time within this theater of operations. The Germans are only missing the non-mechanized corps they had garrisoning their western conquests. The Turks are minus the three corps they kept in their Caucasus and Syrian border areas. Similarly, the Soviets have everything they had available historically in the regions of the USSR lying west of the Urals, north of the Caucasus and south of the Arctic. Their reinforcements are based on what they put together during the first three months of the historic war in the east. Their Independent Coastal Army wasn’t organized historically until soon after the start of Operation Barbarossa; however – given the geo-strategic circumstances of this might-have-been war and the fact the resources needed to organize it already existed at this time – it was only reasonable to include the ICA as a starting Soviet unit.

A hand sensing, light changing, exciting modular game system complete with 5 different modes! Wave your hand over the top to activate the 5 different sections. The 5 modes are Catch Me, Join, Remember, Follow, and DJ

Catch Me: A target color will appear. The five sections will blink on and off with different color lights. Every time the target color appears, move your hand over it to score!

Join: Your goal is to connect the two like colors that appear in the set of five within a few seconds. Wave your hand from the first color to the second to paint The Wave with that color and score!

Remember: A sequence of five lights will appear. After a few seconds the sequence will shuffle itself. By waving your hand from section to section, you can exchange the positions of colors. Recreate the original sequence in time to score!

Follow: The Wave will say a target color and present you with five lights. Wave your hand over the correct one to move to the next level. Each level's difficulty increases by increasing the amount of colors you need to remember in order while decreasing the time and shuffling up the lights each time you hit a correct color!

Make Music: A free play mode where you can make your own jams! Wave your hand over a section to turn it on, triggering a music loop to play until the section is turned off. Hold your hand over a section to play an alternate loop of the same type. Combine different music loops and explore the beginnings of becoming a new DJ!

Hail Caesar is a game of tabletop battles with model soldiers set in the Ancients era. Pit your wits and tactics against your friends as your armies clash in combat on the tabletop.

The Conquest of Gaul starter set gives you two starter forces the barbaric Celts and the legions of Imperial Rome and the glorious Hail ­Caesar rulebook.

This boxed game is just the start of your journey to conquer all comers and write your name in the annals of history!

Hail ­Caesar - Conquest of Gaul contains:

Full-colour 192 ­page hardback Hail ­Caesar rulebook

94 multi-pose, hard plastic 28mm miniatures:

30 Imperial ­Roman Legionaries
    Roman Scorpion catapult and crew
    60 Celt Warriors

Queen Strike combines a 3D holographic display with a traditional board game to bring you a new and exciting interactive experience. As little heroes of the "Music Kingdom", your quest is to collect musical notes in the kingdom and complete the fabled "Rainbow Score". Begin your adventure from one of the four starting points. Overcome treacherous traps set by the "Queen of Hearts" as she seeks discord! Roll the dice, explore different areas, and thwart the queen's plan by defeating her guards. Get to the castle, undo the queen's magic spell, and save the kingdom!

Queen Strike is a co-operative game. Players take turns rolling the movement dice and moving their hero pawn along the game map to collect the musical notes. They might encounter the Queen's guard and enter the "combat mode" displayed in the 3D holographic platform (driven by a game app on the player's own tablet), in which players need to use their combat cards to defeat the guard (in a rock-paper-scissors system). Players might also run into some event cards that bring them some surprise animation in the holographic movie. Once the players collect enough musical notes, they may challenge the Queen to win the game!

During the so called Spanish Golden Age, some of the most influential literary figures gather in Madrid. They are here to compete for acceptance amongst the general public and gain admiration and respect from fellow writers.  Success within these circles requires extreme levels of merit, however Lope de Vega has organised a public competition, in honor of San Isidro, so that novice poets can rub shoulders with the greats and perhaps even earn a place amongst them.

In El Soneto players take the role of these novice poets who aspire to win Lope de Vega’s competition. In order to do this, each player must choose letter cards that are displayed within the famous gossip mills of Madrid, and with them they must create words for three rounds whilst respecting the grammatical rules that each of these rounds permits. Prestige will be given in a number of ways to players for their words: direct points for the number of letter cards used; favor of the benefactors if the word begins with one of the three letters that the benefactors have asked for; support of the writers if the word has employed one or more of the permitted literary devices; or they can advance on the Soneto marker if their words rhyme.

The literati and the benefactors that each player has earned throughout the game will be awarded additional prestige points at the end, in addition to the level reached on the rhyme marker. He who achieves the most prestige points is declared the winner of the competition.

Description in Spanish:
En su Viaje al Parnaso, además de a Lope de Vega, Quevedo o Góngora, Miguel de Cervantes fue reclutando a otros muchos literatos para luchar contra los malos poetas; ¿te habría gustado formar parte de semejante grupo? Pues he aquí el concurso que podría proporcionarte un pasaje en el bajel. El Soneto no es un mero juego, es una competición donde las letras son tan importantes como el arte con el que se utilicen. Así que toma papel y lápiz, sumérgete en los populosos mentideros de la Corte de Madrid en busca de inspiración y del apoyo de los mejores literatos y los más acaudalados valedores, escribe tus palabras y consigue el prestigio necesario para estar entre los elegidos. Sólo hay pasaje para uno.

In this cross between Game Of Thrones and Monty Python become a medieval Lord and puppet master, and use your monstrous and loyal henchmen who will do ANYTHING to help their master satiate his thirst for prestige!

Henchmania is a strategic board game taking place in an odd medieval universe. Each player is the Lord of one family, among four. With the help of your loyal henchmen, capture parts of the city and use your influence to win the battle! The objective is to win as many prestige points as possible in four days, or to be the first player to reach 30 prestige points. There are many ways to earn (and also lose) prestige points! At the end of each day, everyone counts their points before the beginning of the next day.

So battle, strut, pray, denigrate... It's a no-holds-barred war to become the new seneschal of Montfleury!

Take the viral social experience of Escape Rooms to the comfort of your own home and for a fraction of the cost that you would pay! Included in this game are 4 unique 60 minute escape room puzzles that will test your cranial skills. Use images, gears, words, keys, shapes, maps and more to solve the three stages within each escape room. An analog timer on the Chrono Decoder centerpiece incessantly counts down, emitting ominous noises to create an environment shut out from the outside world. If the puzzles stump you for too long, slide a hint card into the Hint Decoder to keep your team moving. Slide 4 keys into the Chrono Decoder when you think you have the answer... but beware, if you're wrong, a precious minute will be taken from you.

The 4 escape rooms vary in difficulty, designed to give any group the experience they expect and deserve. If you're craving more puzzles, Escape Room expansions will be available, but you'll need the base game first as the Chrono Decoder is essential to the experience. Included in the base game in order of difficulty is: Prison Break, Virus, Nuclear Countdown, and Temple of the Aztec

Prison Break: Ten years in prison for a crime you didn't commit. Ten years of your life wasted for being in the wrong place at the wrong time, it hardly seemed fair. You know the guards will reach your cell during the rounds in an hour. Every bone in your body tells you this is the opportunity of a lifetime; you're 60 minutes away from freedom!

Virus: What a time to faint! You swear you could kill your lab partner, but you know that won't be necessary. The liquid that's oozing out of the broken bottle will kill everybody in the room soon enough...

Nuclear Countdown: The table is filled with all kinds of materials that send shivers down your spine. At that moment your phone rings and your worst nightmare becomes reality, the bomb threat is real!

Temple of the Aztec: The stories told about the temple were numerous. Anybody that had entered the temple was never seen again, supposedly killed by vipers. But stories also spoke of the Eye of Aztec, the largest diamond that ever existed

--description from the publisher

This entry is for the original base game, containing the four escape rooms mentioned above.

Several editions of the base game contain different combinations of escape rooms. These editions have separate entries on BGG:

     Escape Room: The Game Prison Break + Virus + Nuclear Countdown (Polish, Estonian, Ukrainian and Italian editions)
     Escape room: Î¤Î¿ Ï€Î±Î¹Ï‡Î½Î¯Î´Î¹ Prison Break + Virus + Temple of the Aztec (Greek edition)
     Escape Room: The Game Prison Break + Virus + Welcome to Funland + Murder Mystery (Second English edition)
     ì´ìŠ¤ì¼€ì´í”„ ë£¸ ë°© íƒˆì¶œ ê²Œìž„ (Escape Room: The Game) Prison Break + Virus + Welcome to Funland + Temple of the Aztec (Korean edition)


One of the escape rooms from this edition has been published separately (in English):

     Escape Room: The Game â€“ Nuclear Countdown

Description from the publisher:

You and your fellow midshipmen are fresh recruits on a British frigate heading to the West Indies. As part of your training, you have been tasked with the navigation of the ship. Compete against your peers to see who can guide the ship on the best course.

In As Seen in the Sky, each player must use their skill to reveal stars and gain way to the vessel's destination. As you practice, you will gain skill and learn tricks to outwit your fellow midshipmen. Earn points while revealing stars and if you can, reveal your hidden constellations to give you a step up on the competition. There will be many challenges in your wake before this trip is over, with squalls and seas that will push your limits. Many can learn the trade, but only one of you can expect a promotion. Who will it be?

On your turn, the player will roll a die to see what the current sea conditions are. Then based on the sea state, the player can use talents they have acquired to manipulate tiles in the night sky, move talents around on their player board, lock visible star coordinates in the sky, gain skill for adding talents to their arsenal, or gain course points for getting your ship closer to its destination. Before handing the die to the next player, you can take one visible unlocked tile from the night sky and place it in their play area, paying the skill needed for the placement. The game ends when all the tiles in the sky have been revealed. Players then reveal their completed constellations to gain bonus course points and the player with the highest course points is declared the winner.

This undated party game was H.P. Gibson's first entry in the field of picture-puzzle party games. Unlike similar games produced by Universal and Party Games Publishers, which usually used decks of 18 cards with single images, the Gibson Series 1 puts 2-3 drawings on each of its 12 cards, for a total of 33 images.

Assuming 4, 8 or 12 players, the cards are then dealt out evenly to players, who get 1.5 minutes to guess the answers on their card(s). When time is up, they pass their cards to the players next to them. Once the cards have made the rounds, the player with the most correct answers wins.

In addition, this title uses the backs of the puzzle cards to offer a second game, Pennies. Each card has 12 clues starting "This PENNY..." and providing a blank where the answer is a word starting with the letters P-E-N. For example, the answer to "This PENNY gets in" is "PENetrate".

Description from the designer:

Feathers & Wax is a solo print & play game using a double sided letter size game board, a standard deck of playing cards and two tokens.  This game is an entry in the 2016 Solitaire Print 'n Play contest.

Daedalus and his son Icarus are imprisoned on the edge of the sea. To escape, Daedalus is searching the labyrinth for feathers and wax to build wings for him and his son so that they can fly to safety.

Once Daedalus has collected his material, he builds two sets of wings. Then, he and his son leap from the tower and attempt to fly to safety. If they get too close to the sun, the wax melts, and some feathers are lost. If they get too close to the sea, some feathers get wet and weighed down and must be shed to keep flying.

If both Daedalus and Icarus can reach the safety of the far off island, they are victorious.

The world's first tabletop novella!

Way out West, in the coldest part of the Wintery Woods lived the ghosts of songs he never played anymore.

Things must be remembered. Ghosts must never fade. Songs will keep you alive, now that the world has ended...

Welcome to Spell Saga ~ realmwalker ~ the world's first tabletop novella! This is a one player solo-style game with magical items, mysterious party members, & dangerous battles. There is no grinding for levels, as the game allows you to grow by exploring.

The ending of any realmwalker is always the same, but how you get there--and IF you get there, is up to you.

Each turn, you get a few cards in your hand, as well as some on the action pile on the table. One of the major finds can be story cards, that move the story (and the game) along. This will also trigger some of the cards (including enemies) in the action pile! You can perform different actions by moving your adventurers to different places - once you have discovered them! The story cards will (eventually) tell you how you can win the game.
Potions Brew is a card game and the winner of the 4th Österreichischen Spieleautorenwettbewerb (Austrian game designer competition).

This undated but early baseball game by Milton Bradley is a spin-and-move affair. The two players race from home plate around the bases and back to home on a field glued to the box bottom.

There are 8 spaces on each side of the diamond plus the squares for the bases. Each side has a red circle, which causes a player landing there to lose a turn. The three bases and home plate must be reached by exact spin.

Using a 4-space spinner, players must spin a 3 to start the game, but go directly to first base if they spin 4 three times before getting a 3.

There also are four hazard spaces on each track. The first, right after 2nd base, means a player is out (and starts over). The second and third, on the final leg, send the player back to third base. And the heartbreaking fourth, on the last space before winning, means the player is out at home.

All rules in the individual aircraft sets have been compiled into one volume of "master rules".
This pdf will be periodically updated to keep pace with rule clarification or adjustments

Contents include:

     Basic rules for flight and combat (included in every TAC aircraft set)
     tail gunners and turrets
     bombing
     dive bombing
     strafing
     ship movement and combat
     torpedo attacks
     flak
     optional rules
     printable templates for tail gunners and turrets
     flak circles (ground-based and naval)

Chicken is a quick, press-your-luck party game for 4-16 players. Based on hot-rod drag-racing, players race towards the edge of a cliff to see who can get closest without going over. Each round the road cards are placed face down. Players then places their marker where they would like to stop. Road cards are flipped over one at a time, with each road card being worth one or two points and the cliff is worth three. Players earn all points from the beginning to where they stop, unless they go over the cliff and forfeit all points gained for the round. The first player to 30 points wins.

This is a paper and pencil party game designed to be played in a large gathering, generally in tables of four with players on opposite sides acting as partners. The objective is to draw the creature shown on the score sheet. Two creatures are available, a giraffe and a penguin. The game includes 25 player sheets, each with squares for 12 drawings.

Players take turns rolling a die, with each number corresponding to a particular part of the creature's body. A roll of 6 is needed to start a drawing, and when one is rolled, both partners can draw the body. A five must be rolled next, and again allows both partners to draw the head. After that, each partner rolls only for his own drawing.

The first player to complete a drawing yells "Gooffy" and the players then tally their individual scores (one point per body part). The two highest scorers move to the next table for another round, and the game continues for as many as 12 rounds. The player with the highest total points at the end of the game wins.

The giraffe needs a tail (4), a neck (3), two ears and an eye (2) and four legs (1). The penguin needs a beak (4), one eye (3), two feet (2) and two flippers (1). Each roll only allows one of the corresponding parts to be added.

All aboard! If you want to set off on your journey, you have to find 8 passengers and then the driver, quickly! Will you be the first to fill your train?
In this pick up and deliver game, players will try to fulfill their 6 wagons with corresponding passengers by picking them up along train tracks.
On their turn, a player picks a new passenger randomly from the passenger bag and puts it on the board. Then this player moves their train along train track by choosing one color track. They can ride along this track and pick up a passenger if corresponding to a needed color. Or They can stop in a train station and change track on their next turn.
First player to collect 6 passenger win the game.

Deutschland's Kolonien-Spiel ("Germany's Colonies Game") is a game published in Germany around 1890, in which players move tokens around a map to visit different German colonies, paying to see the sites and learn about these places.

It's a roll and move racing game - first player to reach the China space wins.

It's the Tipsy, Topsy Numbers Game that includes three levels of play: number recognition, counting and addition! Pick a card and practice counting or adding the puppies and checking your answer by balancing numbers and puppies on the adorable scale! It's an entertaining way to introduce children to math and get them excited about learning! For 1 to 4 players, ages 3 and up. Children also have fun weighing other household items...how many puppies does this or that toy weigh? And the puppies are toys themselves, too! It's tons of fun with STEM! Colors will vary.

Soqquadro Outdoor is the outdoor version of Soqquadro.

Just like the basic version of Soqquadro, you draw a card from a deck and search for an object that satisfies the request on the card, all in real time. When you find the object, place it on the table and draw another card. 
Soqquadro Outdoor is simpler than the original game, since it comes with only one deck. There are no pawns nor score boards: the game ends when a player finds a certain amount of objects (depending on the number of players). All the cards have simple requirements and are designed specifically for outdoor playing.
Soqquadro Outdoor is perfect for children and families.

Avenue is a quick and exciting family game that can be played with up to ten players with very little downtime. Players draw a network of roads on their player sheet, trying to connect their farms and castles to grapes. Each round, a card is drawn that shows which type of road the players must draw. Some cards are marked as scoring cards, and when the fourth scoring card is drawn, a new farm is scored. The order in which the farms are scored is revealed one-by-one throughout the game, so players must constantly adapt their strategies.

When a scoring takes place, you score points for every grape that your farm is connected to — but you shouldn't be too greedy because if a farm is not connected to more grapes than your previous farm, you lose points! Scoring many points early will therefore make things difficult later. This keeps the game exciting until the end.

—description from the publisher

Desolate Front is an alternate World War I card game in which myth and magic fight side by side with science and technology.

Players use soldiers, officers, heroes and other items, such as The Master of the Hunt and Frankenstein's Creature, to try to take control of the battlefield. Use the latest equipment, stalwart allies, and powerful magic to vanquish your opponent's characters and secure key areas in your advance to victory.

Mansions of Madness: Second Edition is a fully co-operative, app-driven board game of horror and mystery for one to five players that takes place in the same universe as Eldritch Horror and Elder Sign. Let the immersive app guide you through the veiled streets of Innsmouth and the haunted corridors of Arkham's cursed mansions as you search for answers and respite. Eight brave investigators stand ready to confront four scenarios of fear and mystery, collecting weapons, tools, and information, solving complex puzzles, and fighting monsters, insanity, and death. Open the door and step inside these hair-raising Mansions of Madness: Second Edition. It will take more than just survival to conquer the evils terrorizing this town.

In the game, players try to find items in the pictures on the cards in front of them. Each time an item is found, that player discards a card. First player to get rid of all their cards wins.

From the box:

Explore 12 beloved Disney realms, from Radiator Springs and Alice's Wonderland to Peter Pan's Never Land and Pooh's Hundred Acre Wood. Be the first to find the hidden treasures to win!

Description from the publisher:

Checkpoint Charlie is a game of observation, deduction, and mental agility. Watch all the suspects carefully and find out which of them is the chief of spies using the clues that you and the other investigators uncover. Be the first to find the chief of spies and become the best hound dog!

In the game, each player receives a clue that reveals one out of five possible traits of the chief of spies. Each player keeps revealing cards, indicating whether each character is a suspect or not. As the game progresses, players gather more and more clues to lead them towards the chief of spies. This chief of spies will coincide with five out of five possible clues, and his aides will match four out of those five. Whoever accuses the chief of spies on time gets the most points. Players who accuse the aides will also earn some points, while the other players might not receive any points at all — or even negative rewards. The game includes two optional rules that add more strategy to the gameplay.

Checkpoint Charlie is set during the cold war, and the subject of detectives and spies is applied using cartoon-stylized dogs and cats.

Activity 25th anniversary edition is special edition to the 25th anniversary of the hit among the party-games. As before, three difficulty levels and three ways of the explanation, but there are new words. The new design will make the game even more active!

This is a party game from Piatnik played in 2-4 teams with at least 2 players each. The teams' meeples move over the board, the goal is to reach the finish. Depending on the sort of field they are currently standing at, one player has to act (pantomime) or to describe or to paint a phrase given on a card and the other members of his team have to find out what that should be. If they manage to do so, their meeple moves forward.
There are several editions and expansions for this game.

A German Shepherd, a Poodle, a Whippet, a Boxer, a Labrador, and a Fox terrier take a break from their masters in order to experience an adventure in town.

But they aren't used to taking care of themselves though. They need you, your family, and your friends to care for them!

You have to decide when your dog needs to:


     Beg in restaurants.
     Search through trash.
     Deliver newspapers.
     Fight rival hounds.
     Drink from fountains.
     Piddle on lamp posts.
     Hide from the dogcatcher.


Do it right and your dog could be the first one to bury 3 bones in his den and win the game of A Dog's Life!

Description from the publisher:

Politeia takes the players back to the Persian Wars. Faced with the threat of a Persian invasion, the players must cooperate to defend their civilization. However, the competition for wealth and resources is fierce, as simulated by an inventive action mechanism, and just like the Ancient Greeks, the players are likely to turn their weapons against each other instead.

The different player actions add talents from the stock to the hand and turn those talents into citizens on the board, engaging in peaceful trading or aggressive warfare. Once a player run out of stock, the player with the most citizens left on the board wins.

The game board consists of tiles representing city-states, colonies and diplomatic positions. The player markers represent either talents or citizens and control of the board is determined by area majority.

The players take turns to select actions from a common mancala style action board. They pick up the action markers in one action space and drop them one by one in the spaces of the actions they wish to take, paying a cost equal to the number of action markers already in there.

The actions can broadly be divided into four groups:

1) Acquire talents, either directly through taxes and levies or indirectly through import of resources that can later be exchanged for talents.
2) Invest talents in buildings, providing action benefits, or diplomacy, providing war benefits.
3) Turn talents into citizens, either to consolidate existing city-states or to expand to new city-states.
4) Use citizens to attack other players or defend against the Persians.

The more citizens a player gets to the board, the more talents he or she may generate but the greater the risk if the Persians invade.

The unique action mechanism allows the player to optimize action combinations while at the same time blocking other players' actions by making them more expensive. This opens up several strategic paths, spanning from slow engine building to sudden seizures of area majorities. All game elements have a historical background, making Politeia a game of traditional Euro mechanisms linked by a strong theme.

In Save the Cupcake, one of you has a cupcake, while the other one desires to crush the cupcake in the most epic way possible — by rolling a ball down a hill to run it over.

The Defender of Cupcakes will hide the cupcake in one of many possible locations at the bottom of the hill. The Crusher of Cupcakes will roll four balls down the hill, through an elaborate network of fruit-themed pathways. The Defender and Crusher must cleverly use these pathways to meet their ultimate cupcake goals!

The mystical forest has been home and haven to beasts, spirits, and forgotten gods for thousands of years. While the Haven Guardian slumbers, a nearby human village has grown into a city, hungry to control the powers of the forest. Can the forest creatures discover enough potent lore to defend their ancient home from the oppressive city — or will the city use this lore to power their machines and turn the forest against itself?

The battle for Haven begins!

In Haven, you and your opponent battle for control of a mystical forest. The Haven Guardian, spirit of the forest, sleeps deeply and can no longer protect its kingdom. One of you controls the city in an effort to master the vulnerable forest using "stone lore" and machines. The other plays as the forest and its creatures who defend their home with the aid of "leaf lore" and forest spirits.

To obtain the power needed to oppose your enemy, you must send seekers to compete for the lore controlled by elementals, ancient beings who bestow the lore on those who seek it. Seekers also engage in combat for control of shrines on the board, scoring you bonus points if you occupy a majority of shrines surrounding forest havens. When one type of lore is depleted or one elemental has left the board, the Haven Guardian awakens and the player with the higher score masters the forest — or defends it from harm — and wins the game.

Two rival spymasters know the secret identities of 25 agents. Their teammates know the agents only by their CODENAMES.

In Codenames: Deep Undercover, two teams compete to see who can make contact with all of their agents first. Spymasters give one-word clues that can point to multiple words on the board. Their teammates try to guess words of the right color while avoiding those that belong to the opposing team. And everyone wants to avoid the assassin.

Codenames: Deep Undercover' can be played as a standalone game or combined with other Codenames titles.

Description from the publisher:

The popular Old School Tactical series returns for its second edition with Old School Tactical Volume II: West Front 1944-45. This iteration of the quick to learn, challenging to master, tactical game introduces the Americans to the series. Fight across the European countryside with M-10 tank destroyers and Sherman Easy Eight Tiger tank destroyers. Pile your powerful rifle squads into venerable M5 halftracks or nail an onrushing armored car with a bazooka.  Find your enemy, fix them, flank them, and finish them. If it works on the battlefield it works in Old School Tactical, and it works with minimal fuss and muss.

This is an undated space travel game from Belgium that combines roll-and-move with resource management. The board covers the solar system, and the goal is to accumulate the most money primarily by being the first to land on planets. Landing bonuses range from 100 million for the moon to 1,000 million for Pluto, and there are game end bonuses for last planet, each planet card and most planet cards.

The standard red interplanetary track includes hazards that can bump players onto a useless green track. The red track leads to yellow orbital tracks around each planet, which in turn link to white landing tracks. Players must try to hit cross-over and landing points precisely, and can be damaged or even killed if they land too fast.

On each turn, players declare their acceleration and pay the appropriate amount of fuel, from 1 tonne for 1D6 to 32 tonnes for 6D6. Players may instead spend 5 tonnes for a retro thrust (1D6-3) or 20 tonnes for a super-retro (1D6 in reverse). Players may also spend money for help from an "electronic brain" that allows movement of exactly 1 in either direction for 50 million up to 4 for 400 million.

Players can buy fuel cheaply while on a planet or at double price at any time. It also can be had for free by landing on a space station (25t) and by giving up a turn while on a planet or station (10t). Players can borrow money from the bank if necessary to buy fuel.

The rules are in Flemish and French, and while the game is undated, the box graphic looks a lot like the space ship from the Tintin graphic novels.

This undated card game has a deck of 40 cards with a motor vehicle theme. There are four suits (red, blue, green, yellow) and most of the cards have illustrations of cars, trucks, motorcycles or buses. A few cards (different in each suit) have hazards or stop signs.

The player to the left of the dealer starts by playing his lowest card of any suit. Whoever has the next highest puts it on top, with play continuing until someone plays a stop sign card or until no one can follow. Then the next player starts a different colored suit (missing a turn if he has no other color). Winner is the first to get rid of all his cards.

This is an early 20th Century British game loosely based on the 1904-05 Russo-Japanese war and in particular the Japanese blockade of Port Arthur in the early stages of the war.

The label on the back of the board shows ships of the period along with the Russian and Japanese flags, and has the subtitle: "A Game of Skill Without Intricate Rules".

The board does not make these rules clear, but there is a Start position at the southern end of the Yellow Sea and a web of red lines and dots leading to ports in China, Manchuria and Korea. Seven ports have their names and the word "HOME" in a white box, and there is an additional "HOME" port for Manchuria as a whole.

The board bears the words "Design Registered" and "British Manufacture" but no date, publisher, copyright or patent claim. Given that the Strait of Korea is at the east edge of the map (leaving out the neighboring Tsushima Strait where the climactic naval battle of the war occurred, this game may well have been published in 1904, during the first half of the war.

Ultra 7 is a fast, fun card game with plenty of twists and turns. After being dealt 7 cards each, players take turns playing cards face up onto one of two play piles. The card being played must match the top card in terms of color, number, or suit, and the first player to rid their hand of cards wins. However, the deck also contains an abundance of special cards. For example, the Flip card requires a coin toss, the results of which determine who must draw two cards. The Trade card provides the option of trading hands with another player. The Grab card is a mad grab for spoons (one less than the number of players), with the empty-handed player required to draw two cards. The dreaded Spoiler card can be a major roadblock to winning. The unpredictability these cards bring to Ultra 7 lend it an exciting playfulness that make for a rip-roaring good time.

This 1964 logic game has a mechanic similar to the later Mastermind, but is played with cards and words. There is a deck of 26 Blackout cards, each with a six-letter word on one side, and an irregular inkblot on the other side. There is a second deck of 70 game cards, each of which has a pattern of holes punched through the card.

On each turn, a player takes one of the blackout word cards and places the pattern side underneath the game card. The number of black dots showing is the number of letters in that word card that appear in the game card's word.

Using a scorecard that lists each of the 26 word cards, the player must try one word card after another to determine the six letters represented by his game card, and then work out the right order for the actual word.

The rules provide 5 variants for two players, two variants for party fun, and one for solitaire. In head-to-head play, the player who takes the most cards to succeed loses points equal to his number of turns minus the number taken by his opponent, plus a flat penalty of 3 points for losing. First player to 50 points loses the game.

Description from the publisher:

Do you remember the scandal when Congress members had huge overdrafts in their checking accounts and were not paying it back?  Well this game lets you do it, too!  The goal of the game is to overdraw your checking amount by more than your opponent(s).

Set up the game by placing the numbered cards in 11 face down stacks according to the numbers printed on them (2-12).  The numbers corresponds to the following political job titles: 2 Vice President, 3  President for a Day, 4  Retiring Politician, 5  Cabinet Member, 6  Incumbent Politician, 7  House of Representatives, 8  Politician's Aid, 9  Diplomat, 10  Senator, 11  Political Appointee, and 12 White House Chief of Staff.

During their turn, players roll the dice and take a card matching the number.  The cards instruct the player to record a debit (subtraction) or a credit (addition) in their check register.

The game ends when a player has a full check register page - 20 items.  The winner with the highest overdraft wins!

Two Bible word games in one box.

Bible Spell-A-Gram:  Alphabet tiles are placed face down between the players.  Each player draws 20 tiles and takes turn spelling as many words as they can in 3 minutes.  They replenish tiles at the end of their turn.  First player to spell 10 words wins.

Bible Spell-Across:  Each player gets a set of alphabet tiles and takes turns placing words, crossword style, on a grid on the back of the box.

Description of the publisher:

Continue your own fanciful adventure stories with the spooky addition of Scary Tales, the second installment of StoryLine!  In this simple, beautifully-illustrated card game, three to eight players create a story together, with each player contributing characters, places, objects, and events to the narrative. Two narrator decks and over a hundred story cards are included to provide ample replayability, and Scary Tales introduces cards to add fright and mystery to your tales. Will your villain be a Wicked Vampire or a Mad Scientist? Will their lair be in a Mysterious Swamp or a Haunted Chapel? prepare yourself for a frightful evening; this story is yours for the telling!

Description from the publisher:

Action and goal
You have 3 decks of cards. Terrorists, counter-terrorists and action cards(which help ter. or c.-t. to win battle but you can do not use action card if feel your person card is strong enough).
(1 vs 1) You can mix all cards and play so. Or you can play for any of 2 sides(terrorists or c.-t.).
The goal is to have any card(terrorists or c-t)by the end of the game.

Fun
This game have everything: the capture and release of the hostages, and defuzing bombs, monitoring, not a team playing, and even the invasion of zombies (coming zombies servers apparently). Game have ultimate funy combinations like - 3 meme royalflash kittys or Cheeter or Admin card. 
The game was originally planned on the card field, but in principle has been made for more user-friendly format of the game.
Game developed with well-known CS players with experience of 10 years of playing. 
Skins special forces of many countries.
Playing with humor.
It is interesting to play a lot of micro rounds. When you become pro it will be interesting to play against 2 or three players.
In plans to hold tournaments in the discipline of CS cards.
So you can already start training.

A fast party game in which a player must read an answer among the available 300 and you must be the quickest to find a question.
But you must follow the game rules to do it!

HOW TO FORMULATE A QUESTION:
To be valid, a question must fulfill the following requests:
1: contain at least one of the four random words on the table
2: follow the special rule of the round, if there is one (example: "in rhyme" or "as in a theatrical performance"
3: be new: you are not allowed to repeat questions already made
4: of course, it can have the current answer, as its answer!

L’idea di base del gioco è molto semplice: il giocatore di turno legge una delle 300 risposte scritte sulle carte e il più veloce fra gli altri a fargli la domanda giusta vince la manche!
Ma ovviamente non è tutto qui: ci sono parole obbligatorie da usare, termini troppo ovvi da evitare e 20 bizzarre modalità di gioco da rispettare.

This is a roll and move game with two different playing pieces: pegs and circles (otherwise known as bolts and washers). There are three of each in three colors (black, white and orange. There also is a set of 40 Oh Peg It cards, each with a familiar saying that swaps out a word and replaces it with "peg", and instructions for gaining or losing spaces or points. There is a set of 200 small dried beans as scoring tokens.

A player takes either a set of pegs or one of circles, and rolls one die per turn. He may split the roll between two pieces. If a peg and circle land on the same space, both players score: the pegger (piece landing) gets two points and the player pegged gets one point. The game ends when one player reaches the end of the track with all his pieces, and the winner is the one with the most points at that time.

There are three kinds of special spaces: Double Score does just that for both players pegging on one; Oh Peg It means taking a card from the deck and following instructions; and Chastity Square means no pegging here!

The sexual allusions in this Summer of Love era game are pretty obvious throughout. Aside from the male-female pegging mechanism, the cards also include sayings like "I could have pegged all night", "We'd rather peg than fight", and "Pegging makes the heart grow fonder". A second deck of blank cards is provided for those who want to get more daring or creative.

This gorgeous 1940s game from All-Metal Products Co. is indeed made entirely of metal in the form of a hollow four-inch diameter apple. A metal post is mounted on the bottom of the apple inside, and a metal platter sits on top of the post.

The platter is decorated with pictures of six different fruits: apples, bananas, grapes, pears, cherries and plums. The fruit segments are numbered 1 to 6 as well, and each segment has a small indentation near the center. There is a set of 12 cardboard tokens, two of each fruit.

Players take turns dropping a small green marble onto the spinning platter and seeing where it comes to rest. They claim a corresponding token if still available. The winner is the first to accumulate an agreed number of tokens or number of points on the tokens.

Description from the publisher:

In Super Fighting Robot, you Punch, Block, Counterattack, Pulse, Energize, and Repair your way through the grueling gauntlet that is the Super Fighting Robot Championship! 
Defeat 4 robots plus the final boss challenge to claim supreme victory! The game comes with 8 different robots.

Choose a robot, add their specialized moves cards into the deck, and then battle by drawing and assigning moves 1 at a time to the 2x4 Ring. Cards in slots 1-4 are your opponent's moves and cards in slots 5-8 are yours! Spend energy on power ups to help deliver the final blow, but watch out, energy is in limited supply!

Super Fighting Robot is a solo game designed for the 2016 Solitaire Game Contest.

Description from the publisher:

"Based on the classic computer game"

According to the box:

"You may:
1. Travel the trail
2. Work together to overcome calamities
3. Get at least one member of your party to Oregon
4. Stop and rest
5. Decide which of your friends will  die of dysentery
6. Write your name on a tombstone
What is your choice?"

All sorts of gruesome deaths await you and the rest of your wagon party in this official multi-player card game version of the classic computer game. To win you’ll need to keep one player alive all the way from Independence, MO to the Willamette Valley. But between rattlesnakes, starvation, dead oxen, broken bones, dysentery, and a host of other calamities the odds are long . . . almost as long as the Oregon Trail itself.

Players work together to move along the trail, fording rivers and playing Supply Cards to overcome calamities. But be warned–there will be times when it makes sense to let one of your wagon mates succumb to a calamity rather than expend precious supplies. And every time players go the way of all flesh, you’ll flip over the roster card and write their names on tombstones (don’t forget to include a quick epitaph). It’s a great way to relive your fond memories of one of the world’s most beloved computer games, and to kill off your family and friends at the same time.
